item.description:
The book blurb/intro sounds a bit incoherent to me.
In any event, "authenticity" is clearly a normative concept implying a judgment about the worth of something. Unfortunately it is usually thrown around as a self-explanatory descriptive term. Once you think about it there is simply no description of a social practice or artifact that marks it as authentic without recourse to some other evaluative criteria. And in most cases if you are self-consciously asking whether something that you are doing is "authentic" you are past the point of answering the question in the affirmative.
While it is descriptively empty, as far as I can tell, a"authenticity" appeals to people as a shortcut to achieving different varieties of transcendence. But the kind of transcendence that can be bought or achieved via the appropriation of collective memory is rather illusory.
